verses.text: And the LORD answered Job and said:
verses.comment: This verse begins the LORD's final speech to Job, continuing the direct address from previous chapters. The LORD's response signals both judgment and instruction following Job’s questions.

verses.text: "Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct Him? Let him who argues with God answer."
verses.comment: The LORD puts Job’s challenge in perspective, reflecting on the proper approach to divine mystery. Romans 9:20 echoes a similar warning about questioning God's will, pointing to human humility before God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: Then Job answered the LORD and said:
verses.comment: Job’s reply marks his recognition of the LORD’s authority, foreshadowing his later repentance.

verses.text: "Behold, I am insignificant. What can I answer You? I put my hand over my mouth."
verses.comment: Job displays humility, a foundational virtue. Silence before God suggests the necessity of reverence and awe, echoed in Ecclesiastes 5:2 and Job’s later contrition.

verses.text: "I have spoken once, and I will not answer; twice, and I will say no more."
verses.comment: Job surrenders argument, recognizing his limitations. This attitude encourages silent trust in divine wisdom.

verses.text: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said:
verses.comment: God speaks from the whirlwind—a symbol of divine power and majesty, seen also in Exodus 19:18. Theophanies like this point to the mystery of God's presence.

verses.text: "Dress yourself now like a man; I will question you, and you shall answer Me."
verses.comment: The LORD repeats the call for Job to respond, as in Job 38:3. The divine challenge tests Job’s understanding and submission.

verses.text: "Will you really annul My judgment? Will you condemn Me so you may be justified?"
verses.comment: Here, God confronts the tendency to justify oneself at God’s expense. The rhetorical question underscores the perfection of divine justice. Spiritual meaning emphasizes righteous submission to God’s authority.

verses.text: "Do you have an arm like God? Can you thunder with a voice like His?"
verses.comment: These questions highlight God’s omnipotence, echoed throughout the Psalms and Exodus. Physical and spiritual strength belong to God alone.

verses.text: "Adorn yourself with majesty and dignity; clothe yourself with splendor and glory."
verses.comment: God challenges Job to match His glory, alluding to the themes of divine kingship in the Psalms. Majesty and dignity are reserved for the LORD, inviting spiritual humility.

verses.text: "Pour out the overflowings of your anger; look on everyone who is proud and bring him low."
verses.comment: Only God can humble the proud and exercise righteous judgment. Spiritual meaning: Divine justice brings down the arrogant, a theme central to wisdom literature.

verses.text: "Look on everyone who is proud and humble him; crush the wicked where they stand."
verses.comment: This continues the theme of God’s unique authority over the proud and wicked, highlighting God's justice and mercy in the order of creation.

verses.text: "Hide them all in the dust together; bind their faces in darkness."
verses.comment: The imagery of dust and darkness points to divine judgment and the finality of God’s reign, linking with broader biblical motifs of mortality and the fate of the wicked.

verses.text: "Then even I will confess to you that your own right hand can save you."
verses.comment: No human strength or effort can match God's saving power—a subtle anticipation of the necessity of grace, and ultimately Christ as the only true source of salvation.

verses.text: "Behold, Behemoth, which I made as I made you; he eats grass like an ox."
verses.comment: The introduction of Behemoth marks a turn toward God’s creation, illustrating majesty and power. Some interpret Behemoth as a poetic symbol of creaturely strength under God's design.

verses.text: "See now, his strength is in his loins, and his power is in the muscles of his belly."
verses.comment: Description emphasizes physical might as God’s gift, echoing Psalms’ portrayal of creation’s strength.

verses.text: "He moves his tail like a cedar; the sinews of his thighs are knit together."
verses.comment: The cedar implies grandeur, and the tightly knit sinews reflect God’s craftsmanship in creation.

verses.text: "His bones are tubes of bronze, his limbs like bars of iron."
verses.comment: Behemoth’s form represents unyielding strength, underpinning the lesson that all power originates from God.

verses.text: "He is the first of the works of God; only his Maker can approach him with the sword."
verses.comment: Behemoth’s status as ‘first’ of God’s works may imply both literal and spiritual preeminence among creatures. Only the Creator can master creation, alluding to sovereignty and dependence.

verses.text: "For the mountains yield food for him, where all the wild beasts play."
verses.comment: The mountains as Behemoth’s pasture highlight abundance and provision. God provides for all creatures, reflecting divine generosity.

verses.text: "He lies under the lotus trees, in the shelter of the reeds and in the marsh."
verses.comment: Natural imagery stresses how God gives shelter and sustenance to even the strongest of creatures—pointing to the depths of divine providence.

verses.text: "The lotus trees cover him with their shade; the willows of the brook surround him."
verses.comment: Shelter and shade depict rest and guarding by nature, a motif echoing Psalm 23’s peaceful provision.

verses.text: "Behold, if the river rages, he is not alarmed; he is confident though the Jordan rushes against his mouth."
verses.comment: Behemoth's fearlessness before mighty waters reflects untamed creation subject only to its Maker.

verses.text: "Can anyone take him by the eyes or pierce his nose with a snare?"
verses.comment: The chapter closes with the rhetorical question emphasizing Behemoth’s indomitability. Creation’s mysterious power is a sign of God’s sovereignty, hinting at the need for trustful reverence and not presumption before the divine.
